title: Negotiating Danger, Risk and Safety: An Exploration with Young People in an Urban Neighbourhood
abstractText:
In the current climate of widespread concern about youth crime and violence, this study focuses on the perspectives of young people.  While perceived increases in violent crime are contested, there is however evidence that many young people feel unsafe, and that some young people, particularly boys, adopt strategies like carrying knives and joining gangs, which may perpetuate the very forms of violence from which they are attempting to protect themselves.
 
This study addresses these concerns by investigating the views of young people living in an inner-city London neighbourhood with high levels of social deprivation, crime and gang activity.  Within this setting, the study combines ethnographic research to explore the diversity of perspectives, with intensive participatory research with 20-30 girls and boys in their early teen years to look in depth at the ways in which they understand and manage risks.

The aim is to explore how perspectives are formed and negotiated within a network of social relationships, and the tensions and dilemmas experienced by young people in these negotiations.  In addition, through sharing the early data analysis with participants, the research aims to promote dialogue with young people about managing risk and danger, and about possibilities for change.
